content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int = 3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        throw(ArgumentError("timezone_bumper can only be applied to DateTime objects, not Date objects."))
    end
    return DateTime(dt.year, dt.month, dt.day, dt.hour + bump, dt.minute, dt.second, dt.millisecond)
end
```

This function `timezone_bumper` accepts a `DateTime` object and an integer `bump` representing the number of hours to add to the timestamp. If no `bump` is provided, it defaults to adding 3 hours. The function checks if the input is a `Date` object and throws an error if so, as the function is meant to operate on `DateTime` types only. It then returns a new `DateTime` object with the specified timezone bump.
